title.narrative: COVID-19: Ebeye Solid Waste Management Project

description.narrative: The project will establish a sustainable and effective solid waste management (SWM) system in Ebeye, the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI), by (i) building a high-temperature incinerator and upgrading the dump site, (ii) upgrading and replacing equipment for municipal solid waste management, (iii) strengthening institutional capacity to sustain the SWM services, The project will also prevent the spreading of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) and other transmittable and waterborne diseases through improved medical waste disposal and strengthened medical waste management capacity. A project readiness financing grant was approved in 2019 to prepare the project and facilitate a smooth transition to the project implementation.

description.narrative: The CARES program will provide timely support for urgent public health measures and for the expansion of social and economic assistance. It builds on ADB’s trusted relationship with the Government of Indonesia through longstanding engagement. Indonesia meets all of the access criteria of ADB’s COVID-19 Pandemic Response Option (CPRO) under the Countercyclical Support Facility (CSF), which include robust macroeconomic management, undertaking of key structural reforms, a pro-poor countercyclical expenditure program, and public debt levels maintained at sustainable levels.

description.narrative: The Program will, in the short term, help the Government of Kyrgyz Republic mitigate the significant negative economic and fiscal impact of the coronavirus COVID-19 pandemic. The government's planned fiscal stimulus package will protect essential social services, while taking credible steps to contain the spread of the pandemic and to mitigate its impact on the population. The Program was developed in close coordination and consultation with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), which confirmed in its 2020 Debt Sustainability Analysis (DSA) that the country remains at moderate risk of debt distress, with some room for concessional borrowing.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Active Response and Expenditure Support Program

description.narrative:
The proposed program supports the government’s efforts to counter the impacts of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). As of 18 June 2020, COVID-19 has infected 3,141 people and claimed 58 lives in Thailand. As a result, the government imposed a partial lockdown and travel bans in April and significantly increased health spending. However, while the health impact has been contained, the efforts to flatten the pandemic curve have steepened the recession curve.
With a large tourism sector, strong global supply chain links, and a large base of migrant workers, Thailand’s economy is highly vulnerable to the pandemic. Real gross domestic product (GDP) is forecasted to contract 6.7% in 2020, down from the pre-pandemic projection of 3%.2 An estimated 3.1 million workers are expected to lose their jobs, and 5.2 million people are expected to fall back into poverty. Given the country’s strong regional trade, investment, and labor links, an economic crisis in Thailand could induce large negative spillovers to neighboring countries, particularly Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, and Viet Nam (CLMV).

The proposed program supports the government’s efforts to counter the impacts of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). As of 18 June 2020, COVID-19 has infected 3,141 people and claimed 58 lives in Thailand. As a result, the government imposed a partial lockdown and travel bans in April and significantly increased health spending. However, while the health impact has been contained, the efforts to flatten the pandemic curve have steepened the recession curve.
With a large tourism sector, strong global supply chain links, and a large base of migrant workers, Thailand’s economy is highly vulnerable to the pandemic. Real gross domestic product (GDP) is forecasted to contract 6.7% in 2020, down from the pre-pandemic projection of 3%.2 An estimated 3.1 million workers are expected to lose their jobs, and 5.2 million people are expected to fall back into poverty. Given the country’s strong regional trade, investment, and labor links, an economic crisis in Thailand could induce large negative spillovers to neighboring countries, particularly Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, and Viet Nam (CLMV).

description.narrative: Adverse effects of COVID-19 on businesses and the population reduced

Vanuatu has avoided an outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) through decisive early action to close borders and adopt prevention and containment measures. As of 12 November 2020, the country had only one confirmed case of COVID-19 contained in quarantine after being identified from a repatriation flight. Vanuatu's efforts to prevent the spread of COVID-19 have come at significant economic and social costs. The program will help finance the implementation of the government’s countercyclical response, which is anchored on the Health Preparedness and Response Plan (HPRP) and the Economic Stimulus Program (ESP), to mitigate the socioeconomic consequences of COVID-19. The proposed program is aligned with four operational priorities of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Strategy 2030—(i) addressing remaining poverty and addressing inequalities, (ii) accelerating progress in gender equality, (iii) strengthening governance and institutional capacity, and (iv) promoting rural development and food security. It is also aligned with the Pacific Approach priority of managing risks and building resilience by strengthening the health and agriculture sectors. Vanuatu meets all the CPRO access criteria.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Emergency Assistance for Fighting the COVID-19 Pandemic

description.narrative: The emergency project was prepared in response to the Government of Pakistan's request to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on 25 March 2020 for assistance in managing the outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in Pakistan. The project aims to provide (i) immediate financing to help the government deal with the crisis quickly and flexibly by strengthening its public health preparedness and responsiveness; and (ii) a social protection component for quick financial support to help meet the basic needs of vulnerable and poor segments of society and to stimulate the domestic economy.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Active Response and Expenditure Support Program

description.narrative:
The COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support (CARES) Program, under the Countercyclical Support Facility COVID-19 Pandemic Response Option (CPRO) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), will provide critically needed support to help the government mitigate the severe health, social, and economic impact caused by the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic. ADB's support will allow the government to undertake public expenditures that are essential for supporting vulnerable populations and curtailing spread of the disease.
The ADB CARES Program will contribute directly to the immediate priorities in government's response to the pandemic- the need to improve access to health facilities and care, and protect the weakest economic section of the population and disadvantaged groups. It will contribute to the government's efforts in containing COVID-19 and treating infected people, for free, thus protecting the lives of the poor and vulnerable and preventing them from falling deeper into poverty because of medical expenses. The program also targets providing social assistance and protection over 3 months to more than 800 million people, including families below poverty line, farmers, health care workers, women, women's self-help groups, widows, senior citizens, people with disabilities, low wage earners, and construction workers. Beneficiaries will be reached through established channels under the Pradhan Mantri Garib Kalyan Yojana (PMGKY), or the Prime Minister's Welfare Scheme for the Poor. Food, gas, and cash for the affected and vulnerable beneficiaries will help them endure the shocks induced by the lockdown. Support in these areas will help a quicker economic recovery when the lockdown is eased. Any further fiscal stimulus will be sub-optimal if these urgent concerns are not addressed. The numbers of beneficiaries are detailed in the government's COVID-19 Response Program.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Active Response and Expenditure Support Program

description.narrative: The COVID-19 Active Response and Expenditure Support (CARES) Program will support the Royal Government of Bhutan's fiscal and monetary measures under the Economic Contingency Plan (ECP), comprising three broad approaches: (i) social relief, (ii) fiscal and monetary measures, and (iii) targeted interventions. The CARES Program aims to provide critically needed assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan in mitigating immediate adverse effects of COVID-19 on businesses and the population, especially the women and vulnerable groups. The expenditure plan of the program has a strong gender focus including loans with 3-month deferred payments and micro loans at concessional rates targeting women and cottage and small industries. The program will also support establishing the National Resilient Fund, through which the ECP will be channeled, with a gender-, age-, and disability targeting and monitoring system.

title.narrative: COVID-19: Active Response and Expenditure Support Program

description.narrative: The CARES program provides budgetary support to meet the development financing needs arising from the government's countercyclical pandemic response measures. The program is aligned with the following impact: adverse impacts of COVID-19 on the population's health, incomes, and economic opportunities as well as macroeconomic stability mitigated. The effect of the reforms is the COVID-19 outbreak more effectively managed and its adverse social and economic impacts reduced. The program has three outputs: (i) the COVID-19 response and health system strengthening measures implemented; (ii) social protection for the poor households expanded; and (iii) affected sectors supported to prevent job losses from the economic downturn. The program is aligned with the ADB's country partnership strategy, 2017-2021 for Afghanistan and the government's development strategy under the Afghanistan National Peace and Development Frameworks (ANPDF I and draft ANPDF II) and Self-Reliance for Mutual Accountability Framework.

The Program supports Georgia's return to inclusive economic growth by addressing longstanding institutional fragilities that were further exposed as a result of the COVID-19 crisis. The Program is aligned with ADB's Strategy 2030, including operational priorities on addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, accelerating progress in gender equality, strengthening governance and institutional capacity. The Program is also aligned with the ADB Country Partnership Strategy, 20182022 for Georgia.

description.narrative: Adverse effects of COVID-19 on citizens and businesses reduced

Among the Pacific developing member countries of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), only PNG is currently affected by community transmission of the coronavirus disease (COVID19). The country is classified as a small island developing state, in a fragile and conflict-affected situation. It exhibits vulnerabilities in its economy and health system, limited fiscal space, and significant reliance on development partners to help it achieve its development objectives. The economy is projected to contract by 2.9% in 2020, and poverty and unemployment are rising. To manage the adverse socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19, the government is implementing a $769 million countercyclical program, including an economic stimulus package that encompasses the government’s COVID-19 health, education, and multisector response plans. Collectively, these represent the government’s overall pandemic response plan, and the proposed CPRO will help the government implement it. PNG meets the access criteria of the CPRO.

title.narrative: Coronavirus pandemic: financing deforestation-free supply chains in Africa

description.narrative: Communities in (sub-)tropical Africa dependent on forests for their livelihoods have been hard-hit financially by Covid-19. Investments in the value chains for speciality coffee and cocoa in western and eastern Africa can promote deforestation-free production while also supporting reforestation and economic growth. The Regeneration initiative supports the financing of sustainably produced coffee and cocoa in western and eastern Africa. The initiative is targeting distributors, who can purchase products from smallholders and agricultural cooperatives with the operating capital provided by IKI. The initiative brings together a network of distributors in many African countries that the two implementing organisations have set up in the course of various programmes conducted in recent years. The initiative’s model also has the potential to be expanded step by step to encompass other deforestation-free supply chains, countries and continents. /

title.narrative: Towards sustainable reform: promoting freedom of religion or belief in Armenia

description.narrative: The intended project objectives are as follows: 1. To advance FoRB in Armenia through regular policy work, advocacy efforts and strengthening capacities of religious or belief organizations. 2. To address the issue of teaching religion in schools via research, policy dialogue with the MoESCS (Ministry of Education, Science, Culture and Sport), and building credible alternative options for opt-outs. 3. To contribute to the improvement of the quality and professionalism of media publications on issues of tolerance and diversity. The objectives set in the project were mostly met, some activities are not yet implemented and some actions need further work, more time and efforts to be achieved. However, with respect to certain activities, as a result of advocacy work, even better results are achieved than the project initially planned. Objective 1 In order to reach the objective 1 and the outputs set therein, a forum for discussions around issues of FoRB in Armenian and facilitated meetings with ethnic and religious communities continued to be held at the premises of EPF and beyond. This allowed for existing problems and matters of concern for these communities to be voiced, and be integrated into EPF’s policy and advocacy work. On November 4, 2019, Discussion of the Draft Law of the Republic of Armenia “On Ensuring Equality” was held at EPF with the participation of members from Seventh-day Adventist Church, Baha'i community, Armenian Evangelical Church, Assyrian community, local and international organizations (IOs). During the meeting, manifestations of discrimination in Armenia were discussed with participants, the Draft Law on Equality, Justification of the Necessity of the Draft Law, main provisions, Regulations, gaps and concerns were presented by EPF and a discussion followed. During the discussion, the notes of EPF’s annual FoRB conference session on conflicting rights have been used, which proved its crucial importance. EPF believes that through such and subsequent activities it builds the capacities of religious or belief organizations and contributes to the atmosphere of solidarity and tolerance between various minority groups. On November 19, EPF was invited to hold a session on fundamental human rights and freedoms, minority rights and child rights by Yezidi Center for Human Rights. During the meeting, the director of NGO highlighted the role of EPF in protecting the rights of national minorities in Armenia, and in mainstreaming Yezidi issues in particular, as well as expressed willingness to support the further activities of EPF with regard to Yezidi children. Isabella and Nikolay of EPF introduced the concepts of human rights and child rights with a focus on respective national instruments, the Constitution, and initiated a discussion with children, aimed at empowering them by addressing their concerns, interests and needs. On January 23, 2020, a small three-way meeting with activists from the Yezidi community, a Pastor and lawyer at Word of Life Church Armenia, and EPF took place at EPF’s premises. The meeting was initiated by EPF to discuss the developments of the case of a police officer in Armenia who was dismissed from his job for being a member of a religious organization, to exchange contacts and information on recent developments regarding FoRB and other emerging human rights issues in Armenia. Risks of becoming a tool of political speculation, the need for establishing extrajudicial mechanisms to hold people accountable for discriminatory behaviour, the process of constitutional amendments, and so-assumed problematic parts of the Istanbul Convention (according to several religious organizations) have been discussed and explained during the meeting. On February 21, 2020, a discussion around rights and issues of national minorities was held at EPF premises. EPF’s partner human rights organizations, representatives of national minorities, foreign missions in Armenia, and the EU Delegation to Armenia took part in the discussion. The aim of the meeting was to discuss problems within the national minority communities. EPF undertook the responsibility to initiate a meeting with the PM’s Office and address any raising problem accordingly, while international partners expressed willingness to engage and support the process as needed. Following the discussion, EPF engaged with several MPs in this regard and held a meeting with the PM Office on March 9, 2020. As the state of emergency emerged due to COVID-19, EPF was unable to hold regular offline meetings with ethnic and religious communities. However, on April 10, EPF communicated with its beneficiaries to explore their needs and understand if any additional activities are required by EPF to ease the situation, as well as provided EPF staff phone numbers for any emergency where EPF’s involvement and support would be required. EPF received positive feedback from several organizations, including Jehovah’s Witnesses, Seventh-day Adventist Church, Evangelical Church, who mentioned that despite the new circumstances that have created inconveniences, thanks to new technologies, they can hold the religious gatherings. EPF held a series of discussions with Georgia-based partner Tolerance and Diversity Institute (TDI), but given the new circumstances, EPF had to cancel its preparation work for the annual FoRB Conference in Tbilisi, which was initially planned to be held at the end of May 2020. At the beginning of the next reporting period, EPF will publicize the report prepared after the 2019 annual conference on Contemporary Issues of FoRB in Armenia, Georgia, and beyond, which touches upon legal, practical and academic materials and issues on FoRB. EPF remains the main organization in Armenia devoted to protecting FoRB, and the leading organization on the advocacy of Equality Law. During the reporting period, EPF contributed to public discussions and provided recommendations outlining anti-discrimination and freedom of religion-related issues, proposed modifications of Human Rights Action Plan (HRAP) 2019, submitted and initiated discussions on aforementioned issues for HRAP 2020-2022, made recommendations ahead of the 11th EU-Armenia Human Rights Dialogue, provided its contribution on FoRB, the Right of the Child to Education, to Freedom of Thought, Conscience and Religion, Violence against Children, Anti-Discrimination (Equality Law), Draft Law on National Minorities, Judiciary reforms, and amendments to the Law on Non-Governmental Organizations, as well as made an individual submission to the Human Rights Council Universal Periodic Review (UPR) of Armenia during its 35th session. At the time of writing, several major achievements have been registered in this regard. In particular, the restrictions on employment in the law of 04.04.2020 and 01.01.2022 on the Rescue Service, the law of 28.05.2020 - 01.01.2022 and 01.01.2022 on Penitentiary Service, the law of 01․01․2022 on Compulsory Enforcement Service, the law of 02.05.2020 on Public Service of the Republic of Armenia no longer prohibit the employment of members of religious organizations, which is a major achievement in terms of tackling institutional discrimination in Armenia. Such restriction for employment still exists in RA Law on Service in the National Security Bodies and RA Law on Service in Police. It is noteworthy, however, that on February 18, 2020, Armenia’s Constitutional Court declared the religious ban for police officers unlawful and unconstitutional. Objective 2 To find a credible mechanism to opt-out the History of Armenian Apostolic Church (AACh) school subject, EPF had earlier initiated Papers on FoRB and Education. In the reporting period, the policy papers, which explored the possibilities of legal ways to opt-out the subject, address the issue of teaching religion in schools, and presented recommendations focused on FoRB and education issues and were presented to the MoESCS’s consideration during public discussions and private meetings. While the earlier exchange of experiences took place with EPF’s Georgia-based partner TDI, during the reporting period, as the MoESCS initiated discussions over new public education standards, EPF got involved in discussions both on general public education standards, as well as subject-related new standards’ meetings. On October 8, 2019, EPF took part in a discussion of new subject-related education standards for school subjects History of Armenia and the History of AACh, where it raised its concerns over violation of FoRB due to the subject History of AACh and presented its recommendations deriving from Policy Papers. EPF further followed up with the Ministry and sent its written recommendations. On October 8, 2019, EPF took part in two other meetings at the premises of MoESCS and discussed the school subjects on human rights and media literacy. In these meetings, the draft state of the standard of general education developed by the working group was discussed in detail, which defines the competencies of the graduates of the main secondary education program, the expected final results of education, the minimum and maximum volumes of educational workload, and the 4 main components of the content of general education: knowledge, skill, attitude, value system. As EPF and partner organizations had been actively taking part in the HRAP 2020-22 discussions, an action on making the subject alternative had been added in the Action Plan. In November 2019, protests emerged in Armenia demanding for the resignation of the Minister of Education, linked with the new bill that the Ministry proposed, which would make the study of the Armenian language, literature, and history not mandatory for students of the non-humanitarian faculties of the universities and over the subject of the History of AACh being taken out from schools. EPF’s ongoing private discussions with the Ministry focus over the possibility and Ministry’s intention to take out the History of AACh from school curricula completely and integrating sections from the subject into other school subjects, such as the History of Armenia and Sociology. Further public and private discussions with the Ministry are planned to be held in June 2020, and the new standards, outlining that the History of AACh is to be opted out, leaving sections regarding the history of the church integrated into other subjects will be discussed. Objective 3 Several activities envisaged in the project have been successfully implemented to contribute to the improvement of the quality and professionalism of media publications on issues of FoRB, tolerance and diversity by increasing sensitivity of Armenian mass media in their coverage of issues of religious freedom and diversity. Through the religions.am website, in cooperation with Collaboration for Democracy Union (CDU), EPF has been undertaking efforts to raise the level of people's awareness on FoRB and related issues. During the reporting period, the website posted a total of 25 articles in Armenian, 12 articles in English, 160 and 333 materials in Press Review section from Armenian and Russian-language media, respectfully, and 9 photo-materials were posted. EPF’s partner CDU has had problems with registering statistics on the website as the website crashed in November, and google analytics did not record the data. However, during the second half of the reporting year, CDU actively shared the website materials on social media, with many likes and shares followed. Due to the political changes in the country on the one hand, and COVID-19 epidemic, on the other hand, religious issues have not enjoyed as much public interest as during the previous year, and more informative articles on religion, as well as interviews with specific and bold statements on the topic, gained popularity. EPF started the preparation for training with journalists, in particular, with media outlet managers, editors and decision-makers on FoRB and anti-discrimination to be held in March 2020. However, the state of emergency and the pandemic caused the public interest to shift to other health and political-related issues, and the event and this component have been postponed. The topic will reach its peak in gaining public interest once the Draft Law on Equality is brought before the NA, and EPF will undertake extensive work with journalists in this regard. The Annual Media Award Ceremony for the best media coverage on the topic of tolerance towards the religious and national minorities was planned to be held on March 26, 2020. However, the invitations had to be called back and the event was postponed as the pandemic-related situation emerged. The Media Awards are organized with the purpose to encourage balanced and delicate media reporting on tolerance, peaceful coexistence and diversity in Armenia which will promote the development of a tolerant and respectful attitude of the society towards minority communities. The winners this year were selected by a professional jury which reviewed media pieces published from 1 February 2019, to 5 March 2020. This year 34 materials were submitted for consideration, and a total of 9 authors from different media outlets in Armenia were awarded for encouraging prize, special prize, and six applicants awarded 1st to 3rd prizes. For raising visibility about the activity and promote the materials that got prizes, EPF recorded a video with the winning authors, jury members, the Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the Kingdom of the Netherlands to Georgia and Armenia Maaike van Koldam, Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the Republic of Bulgaria to the Republic of Armenia Maria Pavlova Tzotzorkova-Kaymaktchieva, and Representative of the UNHCR in Yerevan Anna-Carin Öst, who all delivered messages to promote tolerance, coexistence and diversity. The video is planned to air on EPF’s Facebook page and Youtube channel on June 12, 2020. The project also allowed EPF to effectively engage in the anti-discrimination policy advocacy through meetings with MoJ, CSOs, making recommendations to these and other stakeholders and providing public speeches at various platforms. During the reporting period, EPF has also led the discussions among stakeholders and brought the draft Equality Law, its relevance and importance to the attention of international partners, civil society organizations and government partners. On October 7, 2019, EPF co-organized a discussion on the Draft Law together with the RA Ministry of Justice, where the Deputy Minister mentioned that the Government is pushing for a broader human rights agenda, and the adoption of the Equality Law is only a part of this broader agenda. Several recommendations made by OSCE/ODIHR, as well as EPF and civil society, have already been met by the MoJ. As the Interim Opinion mentions, there was a need for certain revisions and clarifications regarding concepts and definitions used in the Draft, which have already been modified by the Ministry. Important changes have been done in the Draft regarding legal and judicial procedural parts, which can provide effective protection of rights in proceedings. The matter of discriminatory provisions and clauses in several laws against followers of a religious organization (ie, the Law on Service in Police, the Law on Penitentiary Service, etc.) that do not apply to members of the AACh at the time of employment has been raised during the meeting by EPF. The Deputy MoJ mentioned in this regard, that there are some ongoing processes, and that it might be a separate concern that needs to be addressed. As the next paragraph uncovers, most of these problems have already been addressed in the reporting period. On January 27, 2020, EPF held another meeting with CSOs and IOs in Armenia intending to update each other on the progress of the Draft Law on Equality, discuss ongoing projects in the field of non-discrimination, share information and consolidate efforts by various local and IOs. Action points have been made by the end of the meeting for EPF to update all partners involved on developments and initiate further discussions, to follow and participate in public discussion planned at the National Assembly on hate speech, and for foreign missions and IOs in Armenia to follow-up on the adoption of Equality Law when they meet relevant authorities. On April 22, 2020, as the state of emergency due to the spread of COVID-19 had already emerged, EPF organized an online discussion on the progress and amendments of Draft Law “On Ensuring Equality”. EPF used its anti-discrimination-focused mailing list (ad@epfound.am) to have the participation of all interested partners and held an intensive and detailed meeting, where matters and timelines regarding the process of adoption, observations of the Office of the PM, tactical changes, distribution of the burden of proof, observations and recommendations of CSOs have been discussed with partner organizations, MoJ, MPs of NA’s Standing Committee on Human Rights, and Ombudsman’s Office. To EPF’s knowledge, the Draft Law will be brought to NA during its autumn sessions in 2020. Throughout all the activities, EPF has ensured the visibility and ownership of the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands through banners, disclaimers, announcements, media materials, etc., during formal and informal events.

The project addresses the issues of freedom of religion or belief in the Republic of Armenia with a focus on the new draft law on Freedom of Conscience and Religious Organizations, violations of FoRB of children and parents in public education as well as enhancing the implementation of the soon to be adopted law on Equality. As a part of the project an informal forum for discussions will be established for religious or belief communities, several conferences tackling FoRB issues in Armenia and Georgia will be conducted; trainings and annual media award for journalists will be performed, journalists and media outlets will be further sensitized on the issues of FoRB. EPF will work with the Office of Human Rights Defender and Equality body on concrete cases of violations of FoRB in Armenia in order to create positive precedents and encourage others to use this mechanism for better human rights protection. Stronger networks of religious organizations will be supported which will jointly advocate for improvements of the law. In the sphere of education, EPF will explore options for opt-outs and communicate these to the school councils and religious communities.

The annual analytical narrative progress report of the project Towards sustainable reform: promoting freedom of religion or belief in Armenia covers the reporting period of June 1, 2019- May 31, 2020.

Specifically, three grantee participations on a key advocacy event were supported during 2020: 1) Fundación Puntos de Encuentro, XIV Conferencia Regional sobre la Mujer de América Latina y el Caribe, January 27-31, Santiago, Chile; 2) El Chañar, I Encuentro Nacional de Mujeres Sin Tierra Brasilia ¡Mujeres en Lucha, Sembrando Resistencia!, Brasilia, Brasil, March 2020, 3) RMNP, Conferência Internacional - Brasil na África/África no Brasil, February 2-7, Lagos. After that the activities were suspended due to COVID situation.

title.narrative: Leading from the South- Linking and Learning

description.narrative: Grassroots, intermediate and large southern women´s rights organisations (SWROs).
Support to linking and learning activities that leads to capacity development, specially on the field of L&A.
To strengthen the capacity of SWROs to advance women’s rights and gender equality. To increase women leadership.

recipient-region.narrative: LFS covers 21 OECD countries in Latinamerica.

description.narrative: Four main activities were conducted in terms of Linking and Learning during 2020: 1) Special L&L grants to 16 organisations were awarded within the framework of the special call "Activism in pademic". This activity was designed in 2020 in order to respond to the context of the Covid 19 crisis. The resources initially planned for L&L activities were reallocated to these special grants. 2) Two capacity development workshops on resource mobilisation we conducted at the end of october, 3) The IV Regional Meeting of LFS Coparts in LAC was celebrated on Nov 5-6, on virtual basis, with more that 40 organisations participating (and more than 100 participants), 4) Participation on the IV virtual L&L meeting, for the LFS Consortium (Nov, 23, 24, 25 and 26). Only the first activity mentioned (16 special grants awarded) was fiananced with L&L budget (Eur 110.000). Activities # 2, 3 and 4 were supported making use of FMS overhead for LFS.

Includes: Platform for virtual meetings (Design and implementation of a Tool Box to promote the exchange of materials among grantees), celebration of the III Regional Grantees Meetings for LFS coparts in LAC (October, 2019; Montevideo, Uruguay); participation in the Annual Face to Face meetings among Southern Regional Women's Funds (November, 2019; Ghana).

Includes: Regional meetings with grantees, Workshops for SGO, Participation in the Annual Face to Face meetings among Southern Regional Women's Funds, Organization and logistic of the Latin America Face to Face meeting among Southern Regional Women's Funds, Platform for virtual meetings.

Includes: Regional meetings with grantees, Workshops for SGO, Participation in the Annual Face to Face meetings among Southern Regional Women's Funds, Organization and logistic of the Latin America Face to Face meeting among Southern Regional Women's Funds, Platform for virtual meetings.

Includes: platform for virtual meetings; maintenance of a virtual Tool Box to promote the exchange of materials among grantees; social media and web site related expenditures. As a consequence of the COVID situation, the mayority of the L&L activities are stopped.

title.narrative: Strengthening accountability to affected populations through independent perception monitoring in Burkina Faso

description.narrative: Affected people’s perceptions of humanitarian ongoing response of COVID-19

Expense for H2H Burkina Faso for Jun - Oct 2020
(SGA ref: H2H_2020_BF2_GTS)

Objectives are to obtain regular, actionable information from affected people about how they perceive implementation of the ongoing response in Burkina Faso, and the shift to the COVID-19 response, as the basis for performance monitoring and course correction

Target are people affected by the humanitarian crisis and COV crisis. It targets two of the five affected regions in Burkina Faso (Boucle du Mouhoun, Centre-Nord, Nord, Sahel, and Est) which are Centre Nord and Sahel.
Sample size 400 (telephonic) and 400 (in person) for data collection on region Centre Nord and Sahel

title.narrative: Perceptions of a Pandemic: Strengthening the quality and relevance of the COVID-19 global response through community input

description.narrative:
Expense for H2H Covid starting from June 2020
(SGA ref: H2H_2020_CV2_1_GTS)

Response wide COVID – 19 GLOBAL SUPPORT community perception.
Communication with and accountability to communities affected by the crisis
Target group will be affected people in Syria, Uganda, Iraq, Bangladesh, and Somalia.

To better understand how information on COVID-19 has reached populations in several observed and affected countries and influenced trust, behaviour and economic status. The ongoing response is informed by and adapted to the perspectives of affected and at-risk communities in humanitarian settings, at both national and global levels. Global perceptions trend analysis helps to inform global research and learning for future emergencies and the ongoing response to COVID-19 into the future

The Australian Awards Pacific Scholarships (AAPS)is a multi-country initiative that provides access for developing country nationals to tertiary education in Pacific institutions every year. Study areas are based on respective Pacific countries Government's priority areas as well as those of the Australian Aid program. In many of these countries there are no universities located within country and this program forms an important part of each country's overall tertiary training needs. Previous scholars now hold important roles in government and industry. The program collaborates closely with the New Zealand program as well as the respective Pacific Islands Government's own scholarships program. The total value of this initiative for all Pacific countries is $38.6 million over 10 years, starting 2009-10.

The Australian Awards Pacific Scholarships (AAPS)is a multi-country initiative that provides access for developing country nationals to tertiary education in Pacific institutions every year. Study areas are based on respective Pacific countries Government's priority areas as well as those of the Australian Aid program. In many of these countries there are no universities located within country and this program forms an important part of each country's overall tertiary training needs. Previous scholars now hold important roles in government and industry. The program collaborates closely with the New Zealand program as well as the respective Pacific Islands Government's own scholarships program. The total value of this initiative for all Pacific countries is $38.6 million over 10 years, starting 2009-10.

The Nauru Public Sector Reform Partnership will support implementation of Government of Nauru strategies for public sector reform, improved economic governance and financial management, with an emphasis on: strengthening the capacity of central agencies to deliver and manage national budgets that are aligned with national development policies and plans; developing and implementing policies that reduce fiscal risks and improve revenue generation, including from state-owned enterprises (SOEs); improving communication between the Government of Nauru and the community on policy development and implementation progress; and improving collection and management of development statistics, to inform policy and measure progress against key development outcomes.

Australia's bilateral aid to the Republic of Palau focuses on the following three strategic objectives: 1. Reducing the threats from explosive remnants of war. Palau was a major battlefield in World War II and the vast amounts of unexploded bombs, mines and artillery shells have been a danger to people and a hindrance to effective land use and development. 2. Achieving greater gender quality and enhancing women's empowerment 3. Co-finance with the World Bank a project that will reform the ICT sector as part of a wider project to lay a new submarine cable that will provide more stable and faster access to the internet for the government, private sector, NGOs, schools and individuals. Australian assistance will focus on providing technical assistance to improve the ICT policy and regulatory environment. Advances in the ICT sector will provide a more enabling environment for the country's development.

Insecurity is an impediment to Afghanistan's development and security costs comprising the single largest share of Afghanistan's budget. In 2012, Australia and the international community made a commitment to assist Afghanistan in financing its security costs for the period 2015 to 2020. Australia's annual US$100 million 'Chicago' commitment is split between the Department of Defence for the NATO Afghan National Army and Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) for the Afghan National Police (ANP). In 2015, DFAT directed its support for the ANP through the Law and Order Trust Fund for Afghanistan (LOTFA), managed by the United Nations Development Programme. In conjunction with the Afghan Ministries of Finance and Internal Affairs, LOTFA administers the payment of police salaries under a broader program of police professionalisation and institutional reform. The total value of this investment is $185.5 million over 5 years, starting 2015-16.

title.narrative: Leveraging Australian expertise to improve learning outcomes in the Indo-Pacific

description.narrative: Australia is a world leader in education delivery, assessment and research. This investment aims to leverage Australian resources and expertise to improve learning outcomes in the Indo-Pacific through access to education resources, knowledge and evidence and learning assessment tools. Activities are responsive to the education challenges of our region including COVID-19 response efforts. A key activity, Australia's partnership with the Australian Council for Educational Research’s (ACER) Centre for Global Education Monitoring (GEM) provides countries with an opportunity to access technical expertise to improve education assessment in our region. Funding under this investment also enables Australian technical input (and representation of regional interests) to global discussion on education, including in the context of the Sustainable Develpment Goals.

Kiribati faces a number of development challenges including: highest number (68%) of Violence Against Women cases out of 9 other Pacific countries conducting the same study; 70% of Tuberculosis cases are in South Tarawa; increases in infant mortality rate as a result of pneumonia, diarrhoea and malnutrition; South Tarawa suffers from severe overcrowding. The Aid Investment Priority and Aid Partnership Arrangement aims to address these issues through delivering assistance that focuses on reducing the spread of communicable diseases, youth crime; alcohol consumption and domestic violence. The Kiribati Health program is identified as a key priority under new Aid Investment Plan (AIP) and Aid Partnership Arrangement and will support ongoing strategic support to the health sector in addressing high burden communicable diseases (tuberculosis, leprosy and Hepatitis B), health system strengthening and preparing and responding to health threats. The World Health Organization's Contingency Fund for Emergencies (CFE) was established in 2015 following a review of the 2014 Ebola outbreak response. Contributions, are mainly used to enable the immediate mobilisation of expert WHO personnel in response to disease outbreaks. In 2017, the CFE enabled 36 outbreak response operations at a cost of US$20.8 million across 23 countries including Madagascar (plague), the Democratic Republic of the Congo (Ebola), Bangladesh (water-borne and vaccine-preventable diseases affecting Rohingya refugees), Fiji and Vanuatu (health emergencies arising from natural disasters). The CFE has proven to be a very effective tool for outbreak containment, as was demonstrated most notably in the case of the previous Ebola outbreak in Likati, DRC, in mid-2017. The proposed contribution of up to $4 million by Australia would position us as the fourth largest donor to the CFE in cumulative terms after Germany, the UK and Japan. Health is an important priority to both Vanuatu and Australia in the National Sustainable Development Plan (NSDP) and the Australia-Vanuatu Aid Partnership Arrangement 2016-19. The investment is designed as a long term fifteen year program. This is the first three year phase. The goal of this investment is for effective delivery of the health components of the NSDP and commitment to health services demanded at national, provincial and local levels by a healthy, secure and productive population. The program has two equally important and mutually reinforcing end of program outcomes : I. Ministry of Health senior staff lead continuous improvement and strengthened accountability of the Vanuatu health sector II. Ministry of Health corporate services, public health and clinic services staff increase delivery of equitable, accessible and better quality essential health services. The total value of this investment is $15 million to be expensed over 3 financial years starting in 2019-20.

Building on Australia's long-standing support to Indonesia on health security, the new Australia-Indonesia Health Security Partnership (AIHSP) will continue to help strengthen Indonesia's ability to mitigate, detect and respond to health emergencies and reduce the threat posed by emerging infectious diseases. It will facilitate better access to senior levels within Indonesian government agencies, particularly in the event of an emerging infestiouc disease threat and to support Indonesia to better equip itself to detect and control pandemic threats to the region, including to Australia and Australians.

description.narrative: Expenses incurred during the financial year 2019/20 for Investments with a start date on or after 1 July 2008

RIDI aims to contribute to inclusive economic growth in the Philippines and achievement of the Philippines development objectives by supporting evidence-based policy and program implementation and by strengthening policy eco-systems. Key thematic areas of focus are: supporting inclusive economic growth; promoting evidence-based policy development; and understanding demographics for policy development. The investment will consolidate initiatives by continuing our engagement with AdRI (currently residual agreements under the now cancelled Trade Facility (INL799)), and two of our key research partnerships, currently under the Research Initiative (INJ168) (a longitudinal study with UNFPA and our partnership with 3ie on impact assessments). The design will also consider other research activities that contribute to the objectives of this investment and Australia’s broader policy interests.

description.narrative: Expenses incurred during the financial year 2019/20 for Investments with a start date on or after 1 July 2008

The Papua New Guinea (PNG) Food Futures Initiative supports a number of rural development activities in agriculture and food security. It includes a broad spectrum of activities aimed at connecting smallholder farmers to markets and creating more efficient agricultural value chains. Activities include support to women in agriculture, digital agriculture solutions, data collection and policy support and capacity building, agricultural education in schools, nutrition, and horticulture, poultry and aquaculture value chain development. The initiative partners with a range of Papua New Guinean, Australian and International organisations and personnel. Given the impact of Covid-19 in Papua New Guinea, activities under the initiative have been adapted to focus even more on food security and economic recovery. The total estimated value of this investment is $7.0 million to be expensed over 4 years, starting during the 2019-20 financial year.

Fundung under this initiative provides assistance to support Samoa's Health Sector to respond to the meassles outbreak (October to December). In addition, activities under the initiative have been adapted to support Samoa's preparations and response to the current health pandemic. Specifically the initiative will provide surge capacity through Emergency Medical Teams for the measles outbreak, public health and clinical advisers to support the transition to recovery phase and public health support for Samoa's preparations for COVID-19 and also to support renovations for isolation wards.

title.narrative: Humanitarian Support for Flood Response in Dili, Timor-Leste

description.narrative: Based on a request from the Government of Timor-Leste, this investment will provide humanitarian support to people affected by the flood that hit Dili on 13 March 2020. The support will be delivered through the Australian Humanitarian Partnership (which includes CARE, Caritas, Oxfam, Plan and World Vision). The support will include relief supplies, reconstruction materials, clean water, sanitation and hygiene and public health messaging on COVID-19. The total value of the investment is $500,000 over six months, starting in 2020.

title.narrative: Reducing the Risk of Corona Virus (COVID - 19) in Bangladesh

description.narrative: The Coronavirus (COVID-19) was declared a pandemic by the Director-General of WHO on 13 March 2020. Global predictions are that the next epicentre of Coronavirus will be the Indian sub-continent, and 30 crore people will be infected. Health specialists think with non-profits joining the government paralleled in reaching its aim of containing the virus will limit the impact on the population. As the disease spreads, there is need for testing facilities to be decentralised. The shortage of food is already being felt in the urban markets. Price of daily necessities is increasing. Poor people are losing their work and earning as daily necessities are not being supplied as before, and people's mobility has halted. DFAT will support and respond to COVID-19 through BRAC by: - Food support for the to 27,000 people through 6,500 households; and - Risk communication and public awareness of COVID-19 reaching at least 5 million households

title.narrative: COVID-19 Pacific Support Package: economic and health impact funding

description.narrative: A grant financing package to support Timor-Leste and Pacific Island Countries’ (PNG, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Fiji, Nauru, Tonga, Tuvalu, Samoa, Kiribati ) response to COVID-19. The package will bolster funds across three key areas: 1) support for direct outbreak preparedness and response 2) support for broader health institutions and systems 3) support for broader economic impacts and recovery. It will use a range of existing country and multi-country mechanisms including budget support to assist in maintaining liquidity, and funding to plan and maintain key services as the virus hits. The total estimated value of this investment is $100.0 million to be expensed during the 2019-20 financial year.

title.narrative: Personal Protective Equipment for Myanmar COVID-19 response

description.narrative: This investment will provide ventilators and personal protective equipment for front line health workers, in response to a request from the Myanmar Government's Ministry of Health and Sport (MOHS). The Myanmar Health and Development Consortium (MHDC) is a locally registered NGO and trusted partner who is supporting MOHS in their COVID-19 response. MHDC will procure and distribute essential, life-saving medical supplies as part of the Ministry led response to the COVID-19 outbreak in Myanmar. The total estimated value of this investment is $0.5 million to be expensed during the 2019-20 financial year.

title.narrative: Support to Bangladesh for COVID-19 Preparedness and Response

description.narrative: The World Food Program (WFP) will utilise this emergency support from Australia to work with the Bangladesh Government to ensure food security for Bangladeshis currently in Covid-19 quarantine in either government or private facilities across the country. WFP will also assist Bangladesh Government procure protective and healthcare equipment for treatment, and equipment to assist build testing capabilities. The emergency support through this investment is aligned with the United Nations and Bangladesh Government's Country Preparedness and Response Plan (CPRP). The total estimated value of this investment is $2.0 million to be expensed during the 2019-20 financial year.

The Samoa Aid Program will undertake a restructuring of its Aid Program to be better positioned to reflect COVID-19 priorities. Funded under this investment includes recruiting a Strategic Program Advisor to provide technical assistance and support to post in reshaping the Aid Program to include COVID-19 measures and to meet strategic development priorities for both Australia and Samoa. The total estimated value for this investment is $1.0 million to be over 3 years, starting during the 2019 - 2020 financial year.

title.narrative: Solomon Islands Disaster Management and Climate Resilience

description.narrative: The Solomon Islands Disaster Management and Climate Resilience investment will: 1) Support the Solomon Islands Government to ensure the National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) and provincial authorities are capable of preparing for and responding to disasters and COVID-19. 2) Strengthen the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) to provide sustained technical disaster preparedness and response support to Solomon Islands 3) Increase climate and disaster resilience in select communities, including in Malaita province The investment will also support disaster response and assistance, replenishing NFI stocks, contributions to ADF HADR exercises in Solomon Islands, humanitarian logistics support and similar activities. The total estimated value of this investment is $2.9 million over 2 years, commencing in the 2019-20 financial year.
